title: Old Types List
content:
![](http://web.archive.org/web/20140725040626im_/http:/typophile.com/files/MC_6643.jpg)

Any ideas on these? I found this list years ago and I'm still trying to identify all, studying the metal ones I have...  
Thank you all!
author: Grey Delacroix

comments.content:
9/10/11 look like Bradley:

[http://mickeyavenue.com/fonts/bradley/](http://web.archive.org/web/20140725040626/http:/mickeyavenue.com/fonts/bradley/ "http://mickeyavenue.com/fonts/bradley/")

This was used recently in the game Castlevania: Lords of Shadow, actually!

I recognize quite a few of these as common 19th century typefaces.  
It would be helpful if you could cut your image into parts and post them separately. If possible no more than about 6 fonts to a post.  
Don

Sure, I'm sorry. Can I post here? This is the first part (1/16). Thank you!

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20140725040626im_/http:/typophile.com/files/01_4361.jpg)

1/16 A variation of 19th century French Ronde scripts. Digital similars include French Script [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/mti/atfrench-script/](http://web.archive.org/web/20140725040626/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/mti/atfrench-script/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/mti/atfrench-script/") Typo Upright [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/bitstream/typo-upright/](http://web.archive.org/web/20140725040626/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/bitstream/typo-upright/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/bitstream/typo-upright/") Linoscript [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/linoscript/](http://web.archive.org/web/20140725040626/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/linoscript/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/linoscript/") Ronde Script [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/grouptype/ronde-script/](http://web.archive.org/web/20140725040626/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/grouptype/ronde-script/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/grouptype/ronde-script/")  
Don

The problem is that here (Italy) this is called «Inglese»... in every variation!  
Thanks, and I'll thank you again in my thesis too...  
Here is the second one (2/16).

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20140725040626im_/http:/typophile.com/files/02_4734.jpg)

Top two lines are Tudor Black, which was a very popular neo-Gothic revival. A staple with most foundries, it was used well into the 20th century. Jazzed up version with inline treatment by Nick Curtis as Fordor Incised NF [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/nicksfonts/fordor-incised-nf/](http://web.archive.org/web/20140725040626/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/nicksfonts/fordor-incised-nf/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/nicksfonts/fordor-incised-nf/")  
Don

Lines three and four are Extended Black by Julius Herriet, patented on June 1, 1869 and sold by Bruce1

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20140725040626im_/http:/typophile.com/files/ExtendedBlackByJuliusHerrietForBruce1869_5049.jpg)
  
AFAIK no digital.  
Don

Tudor Black is available digitally as Tudor Text by Dan Solo via Dover on the [24 Celtic and Medieval Display Fonts CD](http://web.archive.org/web/20140725040626/http:/store.doverpublications.com/0486999602.html).

Thank you!  
Can I post another one (3/16)?

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20140725040626im_/http:/typophile.com/files/03_4036.jpg)

Moritz-Light. Based on holdings of Solotype Dan X Solo.. [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/solotype/moritz/](http://web.archive.org/web/20140725040626/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/solotype/moritz/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/solotype/moritz/")

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20140725040626im_/http:/typophile.com/files/lore1_4291.jpg)

Recent issue, but may be close design: Font Diner/Stuart Sandler/Turnpike [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/fontdiner/turnpike/](http://web.archive.org/web/20140725040626/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/fontdiner/turnpike/)

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20140725040626im_/http:/typophile.com/files/stan1_5404.jpg)

If both lines are same font G does not match Turnpike

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20140725040626im_/http:/typophile.com/files/TurnpikeInUse_4849.jpg)
 I have seen Victorian wide sans but I can't recall the name. Probably something like Lining Gothic Extended, MacKellar Smiths Jordan ca. 1885. The spurred G is similar but not identical  
Don
Don, and the /E looks wider. I agree Turnpike isn't it. Dick

Dick, the problem I see with identifying a Victorian sans is that they got little publicity and were not featured by the foundries. They were used relatively rarely. I think the sample is more likely to have been called a Gothic than a Grotesque, if only because of the leg on the R. Many foundries sold these by number and not by a specific name. If I had to guess a name for it, I would call it simply a Gothic Extended.  
Don
It's not my fault, the quality of the sample obscures the truth...!
